COMPUTER MUSEUM REDESIGN

FINAL RESULT →

A redesign of a site based on findings from a heuristic evaluation, ultimately presented through a developed responsive site. This project had a heavy emphasis on solving established usability issues. The final site was developed using HTML and Sass within 11ty.

  • FALL 2020 / SUMMER 2021
  • UI / UX DESIGN
  • HTML / SASS
  • 11ty
← →

BackGround

To start off this project, students were given both ‘stakeholder’ and ‘designer’ roles and then put into pairs in order to mimic the process of fulfilling goals set by a stakeholder or client. The ‘stakeholder’ performed a heuristic evaluation, analysing every aspect of the site to be redesigned and establishing the user as well as business goals to be addressed, which was then handed off to the 'designer' who came up with possible solutions.

The established user goals were as follows:

  1. Make an appointment.
  2. Get information about the museum such as address and open hours.
  3. Look at museum contents.

The established business goals were as follows:

  1. Market and advertise the museum.
  2. Get users interested and signed up for the museum newsletter.
  3. Get users to sign up for museum visit appointments.

PROBLEMS

A notable issue with the original site was that the site navigation was not consistent in how the navigation would change between pages. Another issue was that the user could not navigate to the homepage through the site itself but instead had to either re-enter the url or use the browser’s previous page button. Site content was also split into many different categories which simply led to being lost on the site. Overall, the site suffered from inconsistent navigation, disorganized information architecture, and lack of content hierarchy.

High Level Priority Guide

High level priority guide.

In line with the established user and business goals as well as the identified problems, I created a high level priority guide and sorted the topics from greatest importance to least.

Detailed Priority Guide

Detailed priority guide.

I then organized the remaining site content into a detailed priority guide.

Wireframe

Mobile wireframe created in Adobe xD.

Web wireframe created in Adobe xD.

Mock Up

Mobile wireframe created in Adobe xD.

Web wireframe created in Adobe xD.

First developed site

The final aspect of this project was to develop the site in 11ty using HTML and SASS. We also utilized Glitch to faciliate more efficient commenting and site sharing. Unsatisfied with the original color scheme, I opted to go for a more computer related aesthetic.

Revised Prototypes

I decided to revisit this project after I finished the semester. I had felt that even though my final result was more concise than the original website, there was still a lot left to be desired, not only in terms of aesthetics but also in its overall user experience.

This time, I decided to go for a single page layout instead of having separate pages because I wanted the user to be able to experience all of the museum's content without any site navigation besides simple scrolling. I had the idea to create a nifty keyboard interaction that would lead the user to the gallery items but I scrapped it in favor of a more straight forward approach.

Second & final Site

Final site home page.

The final site was created in 11ty using HTML and SASS, however without the use of glitch. There is a bigger emphasis on the warning, appointment button, and virtual tour button than the previous rendition, and makes sure to put the museum information front and center.
